metadata.title: Solvothermal synthesis of Z-scheme AgIn5S8/Bi2WO6 nano-heterojunction with excellent performance for photocatalytic degradation and Cr(VI) reduction

sections.text:
lable at ScienceDirect
Contents lists avai
Journal of Alloys and Compounds
journal homepage: http: / /www.elsevier .com/locate/ ja lcom
Solvothermal synthesis of Z-scheme AgIn5S8/Bi2WO6 nanoheterojunction with excellent performance for photocatalytic degradation and Cr(VI) reduction
Qian Zhang a, Mei Wang a, Meiying Ao b, Yingbo Luo a, Aiting Zhang a, Lina Zhao a, Liushui Yan a, Fang Deng a, **, Xubiao Luo a, *
a Key Laboratory of Jiangxi Province for Persistent Contaminants Control and Resources Recycle, Nanchang Hangkong University, Nanchang, 330063, PR China b College of Life Sciences, Jiangxi University of Traditional Chinese Medicine, Nanchang, Jiangxi, 330025, PR China
a r t i c l e i n f o
Article history: Received 3 April 2019 Received in revised form 18 June 2019 Accepted 26 June 2019 Available online 3 July 2019
Keywords: AgIn5S8/Bi2WO6 Z-scheme heterojunction Photocatalytic degradation Cr(VI) reduction Industrial wastewater treatment
* Corresponding author. ** Corresponding author.
E-mail addresses: dengfang40030@126.com (F. (X. Luo).
https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jallcom.2019.06.331 0925-8388/© 2019 Published by Elsevier B.V.
a b s t r a c t
Bifunctional Z-scheme AgIn5S8/Bi2WO6 nano-heterojunctions with excellent performance for photocatalytic degradation of refractory pharmaceutical contaminants and reduction of aqueous Cr(VI) were synthesized by solvothermal method. The photocatalytic degradation performance of AgIn5S8/Bi2WO6 heterojunctions is related with the AgIn5S8 content, and the optimal decomposition efficiency of tetracycline hydrochloride (TC HCl) aqueous solution by 10% AgIn5S8/Bi2WO6 under visible-light irradiation reached 92% within 2 h, which is much higher than that of single AgIn5S8 (53%) and Bi2WO6 (67%) nanoflower. The highest photocatalytic degradation performance of 10% AgIn5S8/Bi2WO6 nanoheterojunction can be put down to the most efficacious separation of photoexcited electrons and holes, and the extremely positive valence band potential of Bi2WO6. The reduction efficiency of Cr(VI) by 10% AgIn5S8/Bi2WO6 heterojunction is more than two times that of pure Bi2WO6, while is still lower than that of pure AgIn5S8, which can be interpreted by the Z-scheme path of e-h transfer in AgIn5S8/Bi2WO6 heterojunctions and the further oxidation of Cr(III) by hydroxyl radicals. The COD removal efficiency of pharmaceutical industry wastewater by the photocatalysis of Z-scheme AgIn5S8/Bi2WO6 heterojunctions reached 77%, indicating that the developed Z-scheme AgIn5S8/Bi2WO6 heterojunctions are promising in efficacious disposal of refractory pharmaceutical contaminants and Cr(VI) in water.
© 2019 Published by Elsevier B.V.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
With the continuous deterioration of the global environment, the efficient elimination of poisonous contaminants in industrial wastewater is still a huge challenge. Industrial wastewater often contains refractory organic contaminants and heavy metals, and chromium (Cr) ions are common toxic heavymetal contaminants in discharged industrial wastewater [1]. Chromium ions exist as two forms: Cr(VI) and Cr(III). Cr(VI) shows strong toxicity and is also cancerigenic, mutagenic and teratogenic to animals and human beings [2e4], whereas Cr(III) is less detrimental, and is easily
Deng), luoxubiao@126.com
deposited as Cr(OH)3 [5]. Thus, it is momentous to develop effective methods for wastewater treatment to remove refractory organic contaminants and reduce Cr(VI) to Cr(III).
Adsorption andmembrane separation have beenwidely utilized to eliminate pollution problems caused by organic contaminants and Cr(VI) [6e8], but these techniques are relatively inefficient and costly [9]. The contaminants are just transferred from one phase to another phase, and are not completely removed. Heterogeneous photocatalysis emerges as a promising choice to remove organic contaminants and Cr(VI) from wastewater by degrading organic contaminants and reducing Cr(VI) to Cr(III) [10e13].
Many photocatalysts have been developed [14e16], and bismuth tungstate (Bi2WO6) has received much concern in virtue of its remarkable physical and chemical properties [17e20]. Additionally, it shows strong photocatalytic oxidation performance in the decomposition of organic contaminants owing to the high valence band (VB) of Bi2WO6 [21,22]. However, the narrow light-absorption
range and high recombination of photogenerated charge carriers of pure Bi2WO6 are unfavorable to its potential applications [23,24]. Many studies have focused on the construction of direct Z-scheme heterojunction photocatalysts using Bi2WO6 and other semiconductors with suitable band structures to overcome these defects, and applied them in degrading organic contaminants [25,26]. For example, Ke et al. designed Z-scheme plasmonic WO3/Bi2WO6 hybrids with Ag decoration with high photocatalytic activity in degrading chlorobenzene [27]. Our research group fabricated Zscheme CuInS2/Bi2WO6 heterojunction, and the CuInS2/Bi2WO6 heterojunction exhibited improved photocatalytic activity in degrading tetracycline hydrochloride (TC HCl) [28]. Despite there are tremendous progress on Bi2WO6-based Z-scheme heterojunction photocatalysts for enhanced photocatalytic degradation performance. However, there are very few reports on how to improve the weak reduction ability of single-component Bi2WO6 due to its relatively positive conduction band (CB). Thus, it is vital to choose suitable semiconductors to fabricate efficient Bi2WO6-based direct Z-scheme heterojunction photocatalysts to increase both the photocatalytic oxidation performance and reduction ability of Bi2WO6.
AgIn5S8 is representative ternary chalcogenide materials with narrow band gap, strong visible-light absorption and relatively negative conduction band [29]. In theory, the band structure of Bi2WO6 and AgIn5S8 can bewell matched, whichmake it possible to construct direct Z-scheme AgIn5S8/Bi2WO6 heterojunctions. The holes with weak oxidation activity in the VB of AgIn5S8 will recombine rapidly with electrons with low reducing power in the CB of Bi2WO6 at the interface of heterojunctions, while holes in the extremely positive VB of Bi2WO6 and electrons in the extremely negative CB of AgIn5S8 will be beneficial to the improvement on both the photocatalytic oxidation performance and reduction ability of this heterojunction.
In our study, novel bifunctional Z-scheme AgIn5S8/Bi2WO6 heterojunctions with excellent photocatalytic degradation performance and enhanced reduction ability were synthesized by solvothermal method. The structure, chemical constitution, morphology, optical property, and other physi-chemical properties were characterized. AgIn5S8/Bi2WO6 heterojunction showed high photocatalytic degradation performance in degrading TC HCl, and also exhibited enhanced photocatalytic reduction ability in reducing aqueous Cr(VI). The mechanism of photocatalytic degradation of refractory pharmaceutical contaminants and reduction of Cr(VI) by Z-scheme AgIn5S8/Bi2WO6 heterojunctions was also explored.

sections.heading: 2.1. Synthesis of AIS/BWO nano-heterojunctions
sections.text:
Firstly, 2.5 mmoL Bi(NO3)3 and 1.25 mmoL Na2WO4 were dissolved in 20mL ethylene glycol and 20mL deionized water, respectively. Na2WO4 solution, Bi(NO3)3 solution and different mass of AgIn5S8 were mixed by magnetic stirrer for 2 h, and then the mixture was transferred to a Teflon-lined autoclave (50mL). The reactionwas allowed to react at 180 C for 24 h, then the Teflonlined autoclave was cooled naturally. The samples were washed using deionized water and anhydrous ethanol, and dried at 50 C for 12 h to acquire AgIn5S8/Bi2WO6 heterojunctions. The samples with different mass percentage of AgIn5S8 were referred to as 5% AIS/BWO, 10% AIS/BWO and 15% AIS/BWO, respectively.
For the synthesis of pristine Bi2WO6 nanoflower, the synthesis of Bi2WO6 is similar to that of AIS/BWO without adding AgIn5S8.

sections.heading: 2.2. Photoelectrochemical measurements
sections.text: Photocurrent and electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) were obtained using CHI660C electrochemical workstation (Chenhua Instrument Co., Ltd., Shanghai, China) in a threeelectrode system which consisted of indium tin oxide (ITO) coated with film of photocatalyst as working electrode, a platinum electrode as counter electrode and a KCl-saturated calomel electrode (SEC) as reference electrode. Photocurrent density and EIS were measured in 0.5mol/L Na2SO4 solution and the mixed solution of 2.5mmol/L K4Fe(CN)6 and 2.5mmol/L K3Fe(CN)6, respectively.

sections.heading: 2.3. Photocatalytic experiments
sections.text:
Under the visible-light illumination of a PLS-SXE300 Xe lamp, photocatalytic degradation performance of pure Bi2WO6, AgIn5S8 and AIS/BWO heterojunctions were assessed by degrading 100mL of 10mLTC HCl and reducing Cr(VI) to Cr(III) in a Double jacketed glass beaker containing 0.03 g of catalyst. After the dark adsorption for 40min, the photocatalytic experiments were carried out. During photocatalytic process, 3mL suspension was withdrawn at 20min intervals, and immediately filtered for the removal of photocatalysts. The filtrate of TC HCl was measured by a Ue3900H UVeVis spectrophotometer (Hitachi, Japan) at a wavelength of 357 nm, and the TC HCl concentration was estimated by a calibration curve. The concentration of Cr(VI) was measured via the standard diphenylcarbazide method.
Some specific scavengers were used to verify the main active species in the photocatalytic system for TC HCl degradation. 10 mL isopropanol (IPA), 10mg p-bezoquinone (BQ), or 10 mL triethanolamine (TEOA) was added as the scavenger for OH, O2 and hþ. The reaction condition was same as that of photodegradation reaction.

sections.heading: 3.1. XRD analysis
sections.text:
Fig. 1 shows the XRD spectra of pure Bi2WO6, AgIn5S8, and AIS/ BWO with different AgIn5S8 content. In the XRD spectra of pure Bi2WO6 nanoflower, the characteristic diffraction peaks at 2q¼ 28.3 ,32.8 ,47.1 ,56.0 correspond to the (131), (002), (202)
and (133) planes of orthorhombic Bi2WO6 (JCPDS No. 39e0256). In case of pure AgIn5S8, the diffraction peaks at 2q of 14.1 , 23.2 , 27.3 , 33.1 correspond well to the (111), (220), (311) and (400) planes of cubic AgIn5S8 (JCPDS No. 25e1329). In the XRD patterns of 5% AIS/ BWO, only the diffraction peaks of Bi2WO6 are observed, and no diffraction peaks of AgIn5S8 were detected owing to low AgIn5S8 content. In case of 10% AIS/BWO heterojunction, we can notice strong diffraction peaks of AgIn5S8 along with the weak diffraction peaks of AgIn5S8 (111) crystalline planes. With increasing the AgIn5S8 content to 15%, the low diffraction peaks of AgIn5S8 (111), (220) and (311) crystalline planes were detected besides strong diffraction peaks of AgIn5S8, indicated the successful fabrication of AIS/BWO heterojunctions by in-situ hydrothermal method.

sections.heading: 3.2. XPS analysis
sections.text:
The surface chemical composition and valence state of 10% AIS/ BWO heterojunction were characterized by XPS. The survey XPS
Fig. 2. XPS patterns of 10% AIS/BWO heterojunctions: (a) typical XPS survey spectrum of 10% In 3d and Bi 4d, (d) core level spectrum for Bi 4f, and (e) core level spectrum for W 4f.
spectrum (Fig. 2a) indicates that 10% AIS/BWO heterojunction contain Ag, In, S, Bi, W and O element. Fig. 2bee reveal the high resolution XPS spectra of Ag 3d, In 3d, Bi 4d, Bi 4f and W 4f for 10% AIS/BWO. The characteristic peaks of Ag 3d peak at approximate 367.4 and 373.4 eV (Fig. 2b) indicate Agþ in crystal structure. The binding energy at approximate 444.8 and 452.3 eV (Fig. 2c) was attributed to In 3d5/2 and In 3d3/2, respectively. The Bi 4d5/2 peak can be observed at 442.3 eV (Fig. 2c), and Bi 4f peaks are located at approximate 116.9 and 161.6 eV (Fig. 2d), which were characteristic of the Bi3þ. The binding energies of W 4f7/2 and W 4f5/2 at 35.4 and 37.6 eV (Fig. 2e) can be put down to that the W atoms exist as þ6 oxidation state.

sections.heading: 3.3. SEM analysis
sections.text:
The SEM images of pure Bi2WO6, pure AgIn5S8 and 10% AIS/BWO heterojunction were shown in Fig. 3. We can observed the three dimensional hierarchical architecture of pure Bi2WO6 with flower-
AIS/BWO heterojunctions, (b) core level spectrum for Ag 3d, (c) core level spectrum for
like morphology and average diameters of about 3 mm (Fig. 3aeb), which were assembled by numerous nanosheets. As is clearly shown in Fig. 3ced, pure AgIn5S8 were made up of aggregated nanoparticles with rough surfaces and average particle size of about 18 nm. The morphologies of 10% AIS/BWO heterojunction (Fig. 3eef) are different from those of pure Bi2WO6, which was attributed to that there is obvious change in the spontaneous assembly of Bi2WO6 nanosheets in presence of AgIn5S8 nanoparticles. There is no regular arrangement of Bi2WO6 nanosheets, and the AgIn5S8 nanoparticles were uniformly scattered on the surface of Bi2WO6 nanosheets.
Fig. S1 (see Supporting information) shows the typical EDS spectrum of pure Bi2WO6, pure AgIn5S8 and 10% AIS/BWO heterojunction. From the EDS spectrum of pure Bi2WO6, the atomic percentage of Bi, W and O is 27.94%, 32.01% and 40.05%, respectively. The atomic percentage of Ag, In and S is 24.89%, 28.77% and 46.35% in pure AgIn5S8, respectively. In the spectrum of 10% AIS/BWO heterojunction, peaks associated with O, W, Bi, Ag, In and S were
observed. The Bi, Wand O peaks result from Bi2WO6. The Ag, In and S peaks originate from the presence of AgIn5S8.

sections.heading: 3.4. TEM and HRTEM analysis
sections.text:
Fig. 4 shows the TEM images of pure Bi2WO6, pure AgIn5S8 and 10% AIS/BWO heterojunction. The microstructure of pure Bi2WO6 is made up of a number of 2D interlaced nanosheets as shown in Fig. 4aeb. In the HRTEM of pure Bi2WO6 (Fig. 4c), the lattice fringe spacings of about 0.195 nm and 0.275 nm correspond to the Bi2WO6 (220) and Bi2WO6 (200) crystal plane, respectively. In Fig. 4dee, the size of AgIn5S8 nanoparticles is in the range from 5 to 10 nm. The lattice fringe spacings of about 0.165 nm and 0.193 nm correspond to AgIn5S8 (533) and AgIn5S8 (440) crystal plane in Fig. 4f. The TEM images of 10% AIS/BWO heterojunction shown in Fig. 4geh, good disperse of AgIn5S8 nanoparticles on the surface of Bi2WO6 2D nanosheets are consistent with the above SEM images. In the HRTEM of 10% AIS/BWO (Fig. 4i), the lattice fringe spacings of about
0.32 nm and 0.63 nm correspond to the Bi2WO6 (131) and AgIn5S8 (111) crystal plane, respectively. The HRTEM analysis combined the above XPS analysis and EDS results further reveals the coexistence of Bi2WO6 and AgIn5S8 in the AIS/BWO heterojunctions.

sections.heading: 3.5. N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms and pore structures
sections.text: The N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms and pore size distribution of pure Bi2WO6, pure AgIn5S8 and AIS/BWO heterojunctions were shown in Fig. S2. Pure Bi2WO6, pure AgIn5S8 and AIS/BWO heterojunctions were classified as type IV isotherms with H3 hysteresis loops, the adsorption capacity of all the photocatalyst materials to N2 are small in the low relative pressure(P/P0< 0.5). With increasing the relative pressure, the adsorption capacity to N2 obviously increased, suggesting the existence of slit-like pores. The pore size is within 2e20 nm. The specific surface area and pore structure of pure Bi2WO6, pure AgIn5S8, and AIS/BWOwere listed in Table S1. As clearly shown in Table S1, The BET surface areas (SBET) of AIS/BWO composites are larger than pure AgIn5S8 and pure Bi2WO6, which have more active sites for better photocatalytic performance.

sections.heading: 3.6. Optical properties
sections.text:
UVeVis spectra of pure AgIn5S8, pure Bi2WO6 and AIS/BWO was shown in Fig. 5a. The visible-light absorption intensity enhanced
prominently with increasing AgIn5S8 content. The band gap energy (Eg) of pure AgIn5S8, Bi2WO6 and AIS/BWO heterojunctions can be obtained on the basis of Tauc equation [30]:
ðahvÞn ¼ k hv Eg
where a, h, and v are the representatives of absorption coefficient, Planck's constant and light frequency, respectively. n values depend upon the type of the transition in photocatalysts. The Eg can be obtained by prolonging the linear segment of (ahv)2 versus hv curves. Definitively, the Eg values of pure AgIn5S8, pure Bi2WO6, 5% AIS/BWO, 10% AIS/BWO and 15% AIS/BWO heterojunctions are respectively 1.84, 2.42, 2.38, 2.33 and 2.00 eV, respectively (Fig. 5b). The band gaps of AIS/BWO heterojunctions reduced prominently with introducing AgIn5S8 nanoparticles. It suggests that 10% AIS/ BWO heterojunction could efficiently utilize visible-light and generate electron-hole pairs compared with pure Bi2WO6.
The CB and VB potential of semiconductors can be calculated by the expression as below [31,32]:
ECB ¼c Ee 0:5Eg
EVB ¼ ECB þ Eg
where c and Ee is the absolute electronegative potential and the potential of free electrons on a hydrogen electrode (about 4.5 eV),
respectively. The ECB of Bi2WO6 and AgIn5S8 is 0.56 and 0.68 eV, respectively. The EVB of Bi2WO6 and AgIn5S8 is 2.97 and 1.16 eV, respectively.

sections.heading: 3.7. PL spectra
sections.text: PL intensity is an important index to reflect the recombination degree of the photogenerated electrons and holes in a semiconductor [33]. In general, the greater intensity signifies the faster recombination efficiency of photogenerated charge carriers. The PL spectra of pure Bi2WO6, pure AgIn5S8 and AIS/BWO were shown in Fig. S3. The PL intensity declines in the following order: Bi2WO6>AgIn5S8>5% BWO/AIS>15% BWO/AIS>10% BWO/AIS. The PL intensity of BWO/AIS is lower than that of pure Bi2WO6 and pure AgIn5S8, and 10% BWO/AIS shows the lowest PL intensity, which indicated that the combination of proper AgIn5S8 content and Bi2WO6 can depress the recombination of photogenerated charge carriers effectively.

sections.heading: 3.8. Photocurrent response and EIS analysis
sections.text:
Fig. 6a shows the photocurrent densityetime (Iet) curves of pure Bi2WO6, pure AgIn5S8 and AIS/BWO coated ITO electrodes for five on-off cycles of visible-light irradiation. The photocurrent increased instantly in case of turning on light, and immediately returned to almost zero values with switching off light, and the photocurrent response was repeatable and relatively stable. The photocurrent densities increase in the following order: Bi2WO6zAgIn5S8<5% BWO/AIS<15% BWO/AIS<10% BWO/AIS. The photogenerated current densities of pure Bi2WO6 and pure AgIn5S8 were
very low, indicating low mobility of the photogenerated electrons and holes in pure Bi2WO6 and pure AgIn5S8. In contrast, the photocurrent values of AIS/BWO were much larger than those of pure Bi2WO6 and pure AgIn5S8, and the photocurrent value of 10% AIS/BWO heterojunction is the highest (5.5 mA/cm2), which further confirm that the 10% AIS/BWO heterojunction show the highest separation efficiency of photoexcited electrons and holes under visible-light illumination.
To obtain deeper insight into charge transfer process in the photocatalysts and at the interface of semiconductor and electrolyte, EIS of pure Bi2WO6, AgIn5S8, and AIS/BWO heterojunctions with different AgIn5S8 content was carried out (Fig. 6b). The arc radius of EIS Nyquist plots can reflect the charge transfer rate at the contact interface between electrolyte solution and working electrode, and small radius of Nyquist semicircles indicated low chargetransfer resistance. The arc radii on EIS Nyquist plots of pure Bi2WO6 and pure AgIn5S8 are much larger than that of AIS/BWO samples, representing the higher charge separation and transfer efficiency of AIS/BWO heterojunctions. The results of photocurrent density, EIS, PL analysis interconsistently confirm combination of Bi2WO6 and AgIn5S8 leads to more efficient separation and interfacial transfer of electron-hole pairs.

sections.heading: 3.9.1. The photocatalytic degradation activities
sections.text:
The visible-light photocatalytic degradation activities of pure
Bi2WO6, pure AgIn5S8 and AIS/BWO heterojunctions were assessed by decomposing TC HCl aqueous solution. The different AgIn5S8 content has notable effect on the photocatalytic degradation
pure AgIn5S8 and AIS/BWO heterojunctions with different content of AgIn5S8.
activities of AIS/BWO heterojunctions (Fig. 7a). The TC HCl degradation efficiency by pure Bi2WO6 and pure AgIn5S8 were 54% and 68%, respectively. The photocatalytic degradation activities of AIS/ BWO heterojunctions enhanced with increasing AgIn5S8 content, and 10% AIS/BWO exhibits the best photocatalytic degradation activities with 92% TC HCl degradation efficiency after 2 h visiblelight illumination, while the photocatalytic activities of AIS/BWO become even worse with further increasing AgIn5S8 content. The order of photocatalytic activities of AIS/BWO is consistent with the photocurrent, and are contrary to the order of PL intensity, which further explains the important roles of the separated electrons and holes in the photocatalytic degradation activities of AIS/BWO heterojunctions.

sections.heading: 3.9.2. The photocatalytic reduction of Cr(VI)
sections.text:
The reduction efficiency of aqueous Cr(VI) to Cr(III) by visible-
light photocatalysis of pure Bi2WO6, pure AgIn5S8, AIS/BWO heterojunctions were also tested (Fig. 7b). Pure Bi2WO6, pure AgIn5S8 and AIS/BWO heterojunctions also showed photocatalytic activities for reducing Cr(VI). The reduction efficiency of aqueous Cr(VI) by pure Bi2WO6 and 5% AIS/BWO, 10% AIS/BWO and 15% AIS/BWO heterojunctions was 22%, 42%, 54% and 64%, respectively. Besides, the reduction efficiency of Cr(VI) on pure AgIn5S8 can reach 98%. The order of photocatalytic reduction performance is not coincident with that of photocatalytic degradation activity. The lower photocatalytic reduction activity of AIS/BWO heterojunctions than that of bare AgIn5S8 can be attributed that highly active OH formed from the reaction of hþ in the VB of Bi2WO6 in the Z-scheme AIS/ BWO heterojunctions with H2O or OH will oxidize Cr(III) to Cr(VI), and the reducing capacity of e in CB of Bi2WO6 is lower than that of e in CB of AgIn5S8 due to the more positive CB potential of pure Bi2WO6 (0.56 V) than that of pure AgIn5S8 ( 0.68 V).

sections.heading: 3.10. Photocatalytic reaction mechanism
sections.text:
To verify themain active species in the photocatalytic system for TC HCl degradation by Z-scheme AIS/BWO heterojunctions, BQ, IPA and TEOA were added as O2 , OH and hþ quenchers, respectively (Fig. 7c). The TC HCl degradation efficiency by Z-scheme AIS/BWO heterojunction is about 92% in lack of quenchers. The TC HCl degradation efficiency decreases to 88% and 75% in presence of IPA and TEOA, respectively. In presence of BQ, the TC HCl degradation efficiency decrease dramatically to 39%. The results of active species trapping experiment indicate that O2 , OH and hþ play collective roles in photocatalytic degradation process.
The main active species of AIS/BWO heterojunctions in the photodegradation TC HCl combined with reduction of Cr(VI) experiment, possible photocatalytic mechanism was inferred
(Fig. 8). Due to the narrow Eg of Bi2WO6 (2.41 eV) and AgIn5S8 (1.84 eV) semiconductors, AgIn5S8 and Bi2WO6 can be excited by visible light to produce photogenerated electrons and holes. If the charge transfer of AIS/BWO heterojunctions abided by that of Type II heterojunction, O2 radicals cannot produced due to the more positive ECB of Bi2WO6 than redox potential of O2/ O2 ( 0.33 eV vs. NHE). If the proposed photocatalytic mechanism of AIS/BWO heterojunctions followed Z scheme heterojunction, some photogenerated e in the CB of AgIn5S8 will react with dissolved O2 to form O2 due to the more negative CB potential, and other e can reduce Cr(VI) to Cr(III). The photogenerated holes (þ2.97 eV vs. NHE) in Bi2WO6 can oxidize hydroxyl ion (OH ) to produce OH since the VB of Bi2WO6 is higher than the redox potential of OH/ OH (þ2.4 eV vs. NHE) [22]. The hþ in the VB of Bi2WO6, O2 and OH can oxidize TC HCl molecules, and e in the CB of AgIn5S8 can reduce Cr(VI) to Cr(III). However, OH radicals can further oxidize Cr(III) to Cr(VI), leading to the lower photocatalytic reduction performance of AIS/BWO heterojunctions than that of pure AgIn5S8 for reducing Cr(VI) to Cr(III). The above analysis indicated that the AIS/ BWO are typical Z-scheme heterojunction photocatalysts.
According to the above analysis, the active species, the photocatalytic degradation process of organic contaminants and the photocatalytic reduction process of Cr(VI) to Cr(III), and partial further oxidation of Cr(III) to Cr(VI) on AIS/BWO heterojunctions can be described as follows:
e ðAgIn5S8ÞþO2/ O 2
AgIn5S8 ! e ðAgIn5S8Þ þ hþðAgIn5S8Þ
e ðBi2WO6Þþ hþðAgIn5S8Þ/recombine
CrðVIÞ !e ðAgIn5S8Þ CrðIIIÞ
e ðAgIn5S8ÞþO2/ O 2
CrðVIÞ ! O 2 CrðIIIÞ
hþðBi2WO6ÞþH2O/ OHþHþ
O 2 þ 2Hþ þ e /H2O2
H2O2 þ e / OHþ OH
Organic pollutants !h þþ OHþ O2 degradation products
Some CrðIIIÞ ! OH CrðVIÞ

sections.heading: 3.11. Practical application of Z-scheme AIS/BWO heterojunction
sections.text: Fig. 9 shows the COD removal of real pharmaceutical wastewater by photocatalysis of Z-scheme AIS/BWOheterojunction. After photocatalytic treatment by Z-scheme AIS/BWO heterojunction, the COD value decreased sharply from 31,500mg/L to 7245mg/L, and COD removal efficiency reach 77% (Fig. 9), indicating that AIS/ BWO holds great potential in wastewater treatment.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusions
sections.text:
Bifunctional Z-scheme AgIn5S8/Bi2WO6 heterojunctions with excellent photocatalytic degradation of refractory pharmaceutical contaminants and reduction of aqueous Cr(VI) were synthesized by solvothermal method. The higher photocatalytic degradation performance of Z-scheme AgIn5S8/Bi2WO6 heterojunction in degrading TC HCl aqueous solution than that of pure AgIn5S8 and Bi2WO6 can be ascribed to their efficient charge separation and transfer via a Z-scheme path. It is noteworthy that the photocatalytic reduction performance of Z-scheme AgIn5S8/Bi2WO6 heterojunction for reducing Cr (VI) to Cr (III) is higher than that of pure Bi2WO6, but is still lower than that of pure AgIn5S8 due to the inverse oxidation of Cr (III) to Cr (VI) by hydroxyl radicals. The insight to reaction mechanism of AgIn5S8/Bi2WO6 for degrading TC HCl and reducing Cr(VI) was proposed. Furthermore, Z-scheme AgIn5S8/Bi2WO6 heterojunction was especially efficacious in the disposal of pharmaceutical wastewater. This work may provide new viewpoint in
developing and applying Z-scheme photocatalyst materials for wastewater purification.

referenceMentions.context: Industrial wastewater often contains refractory organic contaminants and heavy metals, and chromium (Cr) ions are common toxic heavymetal contaminants in discharged industrial wastewater [1].

Adsorption andmembrane separation have beenwidely utilized to eliminate pollution problems caused by organic contaminants and Cr(VI) [6e8], but these techniques are relatively inefficient and costly [9].
Additionally, it shows strong photocatalytic oxidation performance in the decomposition of organic contaminants owing to the high valence band (VB) of Bi2WO6 [21,22].

Many studies have focused on the construction of direct Z-scheme heterojunction photocatalysts using Bi2WO6 and other semiconductors with suitable band structures to overcome these defects, and applied them in degrading organic contaminants [25,26].

Our research group fabricated Zscheme CuInS2/Bi2WO6 heterojunction, and the CuInS2/Bi2WO6 heterojunction exhibited improved photocatalytic activity in degrading tetracycline hydrochloride (TC HCl) [28].
AgIn5S8 is representative ternary chalcogenide materials with narrow band gap, strong visible-light absorption and relatively negative conduction band [29].

metadata.abstractText: Bifunctional Z-scheme AgIn5S8/Bi2WO6 nano-heterojunctions with excellent performance for photocatalytic degradation of refractory pharmaceutical contaminants and reduction of aqueous Cr(VI) were synthesized by solvothermal method. The photocatalytic degradation performance of AgIn5S8/Bi2WO6 heterojunctions is related with the AgIn5S8 content, and the optimal decomposition efficiency of tetracycline hydrochloride (TC HCl) aqueous solution by 10% AgIn5S8/Bi2WO6 under visible-light irradiation reached 92% within 2 h, which is much higher than that of single AgIn5S8 (53%) and Bi2WO6 (67%) nanoflower. The highest photocatalytic degradation performance of 10% AgIn5S8/Bi2WO6 nanoheterojunction can be put down to the most efficacious separation of photoexcited electrons and holes, and the extremely positive valence band potential of Bi2WO6. The reduction efficiency of Cr(VI) by 10% AgIn5S8/Bi2WO6 heterojunction is more than two times that of pure Bi2WO6, while is still lower than that of pure AgIn5S8, which can be interpreted by the Z-scheme path of e-h transfer in AgIn5S8/Bi2WO6 heterojunctions and the further oxidation of Cr(III) by hydroxyl radicals. The COD removal efficiency of pharmaceutical industry wastewater by the photocatalysis of Z-scheme AgIn5S8/Bi2WO6 heterojunctions reached 77%, indicating that the developed Z-scheme AgIn5S8/Bi2WO6 heterojunctions are promising in efficacious disposal of refractory pharmaceutical contaminants and Cr(VI) in water. © 2019 Published by Elsevier B.V.
